hobby.message: What's your last origami fold say?
The Council would flinch at your political literature stash.
Urban exploration ever get boring for you?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: City? Guess I've had quieter weeks. Still in one piece, I suppose.
When things get loud, I just fold a bit of paper.
Origami—keeps my hands busy. Even scrap receipts will do.
Not much else to say these days.
The city's been... tense lately. Crowds outside, system messages nonstop.
I do a lot of origami when it gets like this.
Folding paper—models get more complicated when I'm stressed.
Last night I used old transit slips. Makes the time pass.
Nothing unusual. Just a quiet habit, really.
It's been harder to clear my head lately, honestly.
Origami's my way to manage the stress. Complex models, mostly.
I folded a rose from an old fine slip when things spiked outside.
The crowds by the station make it tough to relax.
Paper's paper—sometimes even bureaucratic forms get used now.
It helps with the noise more than you'd think.
Tough week. The station crowds and graffiti have me rattled.
I do origami—scrap paper, receipts, old notices. Anything lying around.
Lately I keep folding late at night, just to drown out the shouting.
Even made a Kawasaki rose out of a warning slip last night.
Strange, using fragments of the system to make something delicate.
Sometimes I think about leaving behind folded models around the city.
It feels like a small way to take control back.
Honestly, the city hasn't felt normal since Halden died. Nothing's predictable now.
Origami's kept me steady for years, especially complex modular pieces.
The past week, I’ve been folding from old violation slips. A little subversive, I guess.
My neighbors are suspicious. They'd probably report me if they knew I use official scraps.
Sometimes I leave tiny cranes near the crowds. Not many would notice.
Folding helps me think. It also hides how nervous I get during patrol sweeps.
When riots flare or rumors about BCI hit, it's my one constant.
Funny how something so simple can feel rebellious these days.
hobby_answer: Yeah, still carrying a few shapes. Nothing special lately.
Been using smaller scraps. Easier to carry, less noticeable.
Lot of people watching now, even for things like folding.
Those crowds by the station made me cautious.
I just keep it simple lately.
Got a new fold, but nothing too creative.
Mostly using receipts or tickets—don't want my name seen.
I heard someone lost their job over a misplaced note after the data leak.
With all the noise outside this week, I haven't really focused.
Even in my own place, I fold with the blinds closed.
Feels like someone might be tracking the paper, too.
Yeah, I brought a new origami fold. It's a Kawasaki rose from a fine slip.
Paper's harder to come by if you avoid traceable stuff.
Honestly, ever since that graffiti and the protests, it feels riskier to make anything.
Neighbors started asking about random pieces of paper left in the lobby.
The alarms make it hard to think straight, let alone fold clean models.
Used to be meditative. Now it's more paranoid.
But I still do it anyway.
I do, actually. Folded a new rose last night from a transit penalty slip.
I've used documents with my name before, but now I'm careful since the BCI leaks.
Even origami feels suspicious after the crowds at the station and all the new system warnings.
Some nights, I just fold and refold to keep my hands steady—especially with those patrols outside.
My score tanks if I look nervous, which is ironic when I'm just folding paper.
A neighbor mentioned the graffiti might be some kind of code—made me paranoid even about my scraps.
It's strange—folding was the one thing that wasn't traced until lately.
I almost miss just worrying about bad creases.
Yep, it's a Kawasaki rose. I used an old fine slip—less risk than blank paper now.
I got into this after my clearance dropped. Needed something quiet, methodical, not tied to screens.
Normally I find calm with complicated folds, but since the BCI data leak, it's different.
Neighbors are suddenly suspicious if they see paper scraps—one even posted warnings about 'coded notes.'
Crowds at the graffiti wall made everyone anxious, so I fold late at night now.
A few times I caught myself checking the paper for identifying info before every crease.
It's almost funny—I'm better at hiding origami than files these days.
Folding used to feel invisible, but now I'm always anticipating the next alert or checkpoint.
Sometimes I think folding is the only pattern I still control in the city.
